definition: lit. both sleeves flowing in the breeze (idiom); having clean hands/uncorrupted/unsoiled by corrupt practices
two/both/some/a few/tael, unit of weight equal to 50 grams (modern) or 1⁄16 of a catty 斤[jin1] (old)
sleeve/to tuck inside one's sleeve
Qing or Ch'ing dynasty of imperial China (1644-1911)/surname Qing
clear/distinct/quiet/just and honest/pure/to settle or clear up/to clean up or purge
wind/news/style/custom/manner/CL:陣|阵[zhen4],絲|丝[si1]

sentences.english: So I decided to have clean hands to start with small things.
sentences.chinese: 于是两袖清风的我决定从小事情做起。

sentences.english: He had clean hands during his ten years of government service.
